title: Linux lsmod Command with Practical Examples
description: Explore the Linux lsmod command, which displays information about loaded kernel modules. Learn how to load and unload kernel modules, and understand the purpose and output of the lsmod command.

steps.title: Understand the Purpose of lsmod Command

verify.name: Verify lsmod command output
verify.hint: The lsmod command should display a list of currently loaded kernel modules. If the output is empty, it means there are no kernel modules loaded on your system.

steps.title: Explore the Output of lsmod Command

verify.name: Verify lsmod command output format
verify.hint: The output of the lsmod command should have a header row with the column names "Module", "Size", and "Used by". If the output does not match this format, there may be an issue with the command or the system.

verify.name: Verify loading and unloading of kernel module
verify.hint:
The verification script first tries to load the 'vboxguest' kernel module using the 'modprobe' command. It then checks if the module is successfully loaded by searching for it in the output of the 'lsmod' command.

Next, the script tries to unload the 'vboxguest' module using the 'modprobe -r' command. It then checks if the module is successfully unloaded by searching for it in the output of the 'lsmod' command.

If both the loading and unloading of the kernel module are successful, the verification passes. If either of the operations fails, the verification will fail, and the corresponding error message will be displayed.
